argument.major premise: Generally, if a nation faces the threat of complete destruction, then the use of nuclear weapons might occur
argument.minor premise: In this case, our nation is facing the potential for complete destruction by a hostile enemy
argument.conclusion: Therefore, in this case, the use of nuclear weapons might occur.

argument.major premise: Generally, if a nuclear weapon is used, then it will cause catastrophic damage and irreparable harm to both the target and surrounding areas.
argument.minor premise: In this case, a nuclear weapon is used
argument.conclusion: Therefore, the use of a nuclear weapon will cause catastrophic damage and irreparable harm to both the target and surrounding areas.

argument.individual premise: The Atom Bomb has immense destructive potential
argument.classification Premise: For all weapons, if a weapon has immense destructive potential, then it can be classified as a weapon of mass destruction
argument.conclusion: The Atom Bomb is a weapon of mass destruction

argument.individual premise: The use of nuclear weapons causes massive and indiscriminate destruction
argument.classification premise: For all actions that cause massive and indiscriminate destruction, if they are used intentionally, then they can be classified as war crimes according to international laws and conventions
argument.conclusion: The use of nuclear weapons is a war crime according to international laws and conventions

argument.first step premise: The use of nuclear weapons is up for consideration as a proposal that seems initially like something that should be brought about.
argument.recursive premise: Bringing up the use of nuclear weapons would plausibly lead (in the given circumstances, as far as we know) to a catastrophic nuclear war, which would in turn plausibly lead to the destruction of civilization, the loss of countless lives, and the devastation of the planet, and so forth, through the sequence of events that would unfold in the aftermath of such a war.
argument.bad outcome premise: The end result of a catastrophic nuclear war would be a horrible, disastrous, and irreparable outcome.
argument.conclusion: The use of nuclear weapons should not be brought about under any circumstances.

argument.specific premise: The use of nuclear weapons can serve as a deterrent and prevent war through mutual assured destruction.
argument.general premise: When a weapon has the ability to threaten a destructive force that outweighs any potential gains from an attack, it can prevent war and promote peace.
argument.conclusion: The use of nuclear weapons can prevent war and promote peace through deterrence.

argument.specific premise: The use of nuclear weapons would cause catastrophic and long-lasting damage to both human life and the environment
argument.general premise: The principle of the just war, which supports the idea that the use of force must be proportional to the desired outcome, is generally indicated as true when the potential harm of a particular course of action outweighs its potential benefits
argument.conclusion: The use of nuclear weapons is unjustified and contrary to the principle of the just war in this situation

argument.major premise: If the use of nuclear weapons would result in catastrophic consequences, then it would be widely recognized as such.
argument.minor premise: It is not the case that everyone agrees that the use of nuclear weapons would lead to catastrophic consequences.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, it is uncertain whether the use of nuclear weapons would result in catastrophic consequences.

argument.major premise: If using nuclear weapons were justifiable, then it would be widely accepted as valid
argument.minor premise: It is not the case that using nuclear weapons is widely accepted as valid
argument.conclusion: Therefore, using nuclear weapons is not justifiable

argument.premise 1: If you engage in a full-scale military attack on our country, the catastrophic consequences, use of nuclear weapons, will follow.
argument.premise 2: Our country is in a position to use nuclear weapons.
argument.premise 3: We hereby assert that in fact we will use nuclear weapons if you engage in a full-scale military attack on our country.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, you had better not engage in a full-scale military attack on our country.

argument.premise 1: If nuclear weapons are used, it will result in massive destruction and loss of innocent lives.
argument.premise 2: As a member of the international community, I have the power to enforce economic and diplomatic sanctions against any country that uses nuclear weapons.
argument.premise 3: I assert that I will use all means possible to ensure that any country that uses nuclear weapons will face severe economic and diplomatic consequences.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, any country considering the use of nuclear weapons should think twice and abstain from using them to avoid the severe consequences that will follow.

argument.premise 1: If countries possessing nuclear weapons stop trying to use them as a deterrent, all the resources and efforts spent in acquiring and maintaining those weapons will be wasted.
argument.premise 2: If all those efforts are wasted, it would lead to an economic loss for the country and a loss in its perceived power and status in the international community.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, countries possessing nuclear weapons ought to continue trying to use them as a deterrent to realize the benefits of their previous investments.

argument.premise 1: If a nuclear weapon is used, it will result in widespread destruction and loss of life.
argument.premise 2: If all the years of progress and efforts towards creating a peaceful world are destroyed by the use of a nuclear weapon, it would be a waste.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, we ought not to use nuclear weapons and continue to work towards a peaceful world.

argument.premise 1: There is a choice at the present time between using nuclear weapons and not using nuclear weapons
argument.premise 2: At a past time, significant resources were invested in developing and maintaining nuclear weapons capabilities
argument.conclusion: Therefore, we should choose to use nuclear weapons to justify the sunk cost of resources invested in developing and maintaining this capability

argument.premise 1: There is a choice in 2021 between using nuclear weapons and opting for diplomatic negotiations
argument.premise 2: In 1968, we committed to non-use of nuclear weapons because of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons
argument.conclusion: Therefore, we should choose opting for diplomatic negotiations

argument.Position to Know Premise: Dr. John Smith is a retired U.S. Air Force officer with over 30 years of experience in nuclear strategy and policy. He personally participated in exercises and simulations involving the use of nuclear weapons.
argument.Truth Telling Premise: Dr. Smith is a respected expert in his field and has a reputation for honesty and integrity.
argument.Statement Premise: Dr. Smith states that the use of nuclear weapons could be necessary in certain circumstances, such as in response to a catastrophic attack on the United States or its allies that threatens their survival.
argument.Conclusion: Dr. Smith's testimony suggests that the use of nuclear weapons may be justified in extreme situations, and this argument may be plausibly taken to be true based on his expertise and reputation.

argument.Position to Know Premise: Dr. Jane Smith is a nuclear scientist with top-level security clearance and has worked on various nuclear weapons projects
argument.Truth Telling Premise: Dr. Smith has a reputation for honesty and integrity among her colleagues and superiors
argument.Statement Premise: Dr. Smith states that the use of nuclear weapons is not only morally reprehensible but also highly dangerous and counterproductive
argument.Conclusion: Dr. Smith's testimony is credible and based on her extensive knowledge and expertise in nuclear science, and therefore it is reasonable to conclude that the use of nuclear weapons should be avoided at all costs.

argument.Premise 1: Nuclear weapons have had a significant deterrent effect on conflicts between nuclear-armed countries since their initial creation.
argument.Premise 2: The sheer destructive power of nuclear weapons creates a fear of retaliation that can prevent countries from initiating a full-scale war with other nuclear-armed nations.
argument.Premise 3: No alternative explanation has been presented that could effectively provide the same level of deterrence as nuclear weapons.
argument.Conclusion: Therefore, the use of nuclear weapons as a deterrent remains a plausible hypothesis.

argument.Premise 1: The use of nuclear weapons would result in catastrophic global consequences.
argument.Premise 2: The devastation caused by nuclear weapons is beyond repair, and the loss of life and infrastructure would be unimaginable.
argument.Premise 3: No other alternative has been put forward that could mitigate the catastrophic consequences of nuclear weapons.
argument.Conclusion: Therefore, the use of nuclear weapons should not be considered as a plausible solution to any global conflict.

argument.major premise: Philosophers who study concepts of existence and death are in position to know about things in the subject domain of immortality containing proposition that immortality is possible.
argument.minor premise: Various philosophers like Plato, Nietzsche, and Kierkegaard have provided convincing arguments on the possibility of immortality.
argument.conclusion: Immortality is possible.

argument.major premise: No one is in a position to know about things in the subject domain of immortality since it has never been achieved or proven to exist
argument.minor premise: Many assertions about achieving immortality have been made throughout history
argument.conclusion: The assertion of achieving immortality is not true

argument.major premise: Dr. Aubrey de Grey is an expert in the field of biogerontology, which studies the biological processes of aging and their effects on the body.
argument.minor premise: Dr. de Grey asserts that immortality is achievable through scientific advancements in biogerontology.
argument.conclusion: Immortality is a possibility through advancements in biogerontology.

argument.major premise: Dr. John Smith is an expert in the field of human mortality and aging.
argument.minor premise: Dr. Smith asserts that immortality is neither feasible nor desirable for humans.
argument.conclusion: Immortality is not a viable option for humans.

argument.character attack premise: John is a known liar and frequently manipulfs the truth for his own benefit
argument.conclusion: John’s argument against immortality should not be accepted

argument.character attack premise: John is a known fraud and liar
argument.conclusion: John's argument for immortality should not be accepted

argument.initial commitment premise: John has claimed or indicated that he is committed to the idea of immortality through technological advancements
argument.opposed commitment premise: Other evidence in this particular case shows that John is not really committed to the idea of immortality through technological advancements, as he has expressed concerns about overpopulation and environmental sustainability that could result from people becoming immortal
argument.conclusion: John's commitments are inconsistent

argument.initial commitment premise: John has claimed or indicated that he is committed to living forever through advancements in technology
argument.opposed commitment premise: However, John hasn't taken any efforts to pursue these advancements in technology or shown any interest in them.
argument.conclusion: John's commitments are inconsistent

argument.major premise: The desire for immortality is a popular practice among those who are familiar with the concept of death and the limitations of human life
argument.minor premise: If the desire for immortality is a popular practice among those familiar with the concept of death and the limitations of human life, that gives a reason to think that the pursuit of immortality is acceptable
argument.conclusion: Therefore, the pursuit of immortality is acceptable in this case

argument.major premise: The concept of immortality or living forever is generally not accepted among those who are familiar with ethical and moral standards.
argument.minor premise: If the concept of immortality is generally not accepted among those familiar with ethical and moral standards, that gives a reason to think that immortality is not acceptable.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, immortality is not acceptable in this case.

argument.general acceptance premise: The desire for immortality is a common theme in human history, literature, and religion.
argument.presumption premise: If the desire for immortality is a common theme in human history, literature, and religion, that gives a reason in favor of immortality.
argument.conclusion: There is a reason in favor of immortality.

argument.general acceptance premise: Death is a natural and necessary part of life
argument.presumption premise: If death is a natural and necessary part of life, then there is a reason to accept it as a part of the human experience
argument.conclusion: There is a reason to accept death as a part of the human experience.

argument.similarity premise: Generally, biological evolution development is similar to technological development
argument.base premise: Existence-enhancing changes (like better immunity, longer lifespan etc.) have been witnessed in biological evolution development
argument.conclusion: Existence-enhancing changes (including the possibility of immortality) can also occur in technological development

argument.similarity premise: Being immortal is similar to being stuck in a never-ending job
argument.base premise: Being stuck in a never-ending job is a source of great dissatisfaction and mental exhaustion
argument.conclusion: Being immortal will eventually become a source of dissatisfaction and mental exhaustion

argument.major premise: Generally, according to the established rule, if a person is alive, then they will eventually die.
argument.minor premise: In this legitimate case, John Doe has been alive for over 200 years through the use of advanced technology and medical procedures, but he has not died.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, an exception to the rule must be recognized, and the rule appropriately modified or qualified to allow for the possibility of immortality.

argument.premise: In this particular case, the immortal individual has witnessed the death of countless loved ones and has been unable to form new meaningful relationships due to the constant fear of outliving them.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, generally, if an individual is granted immortality, it is likely to cause immense emotional pain and loneliness due to the inability to form lasting relationships and the constant loss of loved ones.

argument.major premise: If achieving immortality through technological means is the established rule for beings who possess the capability, then (unless the being is an exception), those beings must attempt to achieve immortality.
argument.minor premise: Achieving immortality through technological means is the established rule for humans who have the means to pursue it.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, humans who have the means to pursue immortality must attempt to achieve it.

argument.major premise: If experiencing irreversible physical and mental decay is the established rule for mortal beings, then (unless the case is an exception), mortal beings must eventually die.
argument.minor premise: Experiencing irreversible physical and mental decay is the established rule for human beings.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, human beings must eventually die.

argument.major premise: Generally, if medical technology continues to advance at its current rate, then diseases and age-related ailments could be eradicated or significantly reduced
argument.minor premise: In this case, medical technology is advancing at a fast pace
argument.conclusion: Therefore, in this case, immortality, or significantly extended lifespans, might occur

argument.major premise: Generally, if humans do not age and remain alive indefinitely, then overpopulation will occur.
argument.minor premise: In the case of achieving immortality, humans will not age and remain alive indefinitely.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, in this case, overpopulation will occur.

argument.individual premise: John Doe is biologically immortal and cannot die of old age.
argument.classification premise: For all beings that are biologically immortal and cannot die of old age, they possess the property of eternal life.

argument.individual premise: Humans are mortal beings
argument.classification Premise: For all beings that are mortal, they can be classified as having a limited lifespan
argument.conclusion: Therefore, humans can be classified as having a limited lifespan

argument.first step premise: Immortality is up for consideration as a proposal that seems initially like something that should be brought about.
argument.recursive premise: Bringing up Immortality would plausibly lead (in the given circumstances, as far as we know) to the development of technologies that would allow humans to live longer and longer, which would in turn plausibly lead to overpopulation, depletion of resources, and eventually the collapse of the entire human society.
argument.bad outcome premise: The collapse of human society is a horrible (disastrous, bad) outcome.
argument.conclusion: Immortality should not be brought about.

argument.specific premise: Recent advances in biotechnology have allowed for the successful preservation of human organs and tissues for extended periods of time.
argument.general premise: According to the scientific principle of entropy, all living organisms eventually decay and perish, but if the decay process can be halted or slowed down, immortality could be within reach.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, it is possible that immortality could be achieved through the application of biotechnology to preserve and maintain human cells and tissues, as indicated by recent advances in the field.

argument.specific premise: It is impossible to experience every possible outcome in an infinite amount of time.
argument.general premise: Mortality is necessary for us to appreciate the value of time and make the most of limited resources.
argument.conclusion: Immortality would not be desirable as it would decrease our appreciation of the value of time and limit our ability to make meaningful choices.

argument.major premise: If immortality were possible, then it would have been achieved by now
argument.minor premise: It is not the case that immortality has been achieved
argument.conclusion: Therefore, immortality is not possible

argument.premise 1: If you bring about the ban of research on immortality, the consequence of halting human development and progress will follow
argument.premise 2: I am in position to expand and share knowledge about the importance of research on immortality to human development and progress
argument.premise 3: I hereby assert that in fact I will see to it that the importance of research on immortality to human development and progress is widely known if you bring about the ban of research on immortality
argument.conclusion: Therefore, you had better not bring about the ban of research on immortality

argument.premise 1: If immortality is achieved, it will lead to overpopulation and resource depletion that will ultimately lead to the collapse of the human race
argument.premise 2: As a scientist, I play a key role in researching and developing potential methods for achieving immortality
argument.premise 3: I hereby assert that if we continue to pursue immortality without considering its long-term consequences, I will ensure that the resulting population boom and depletion of resources will occur
argument.conclusion: Therefore, we had better not pursue immortality without fully considering its consequences

argument.premise 1: If we accept that death is the end of our existence, all our efforts to improve ourselves and contribute to society will be wasted.
argument.premise 2: If all our previous attempts to improve ourselves and contribute to society are wasted, that would be a bad thing as it would mean that all the progress we have made as individuals and as a society would be lost.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, we ought to strive for immortality so that our efforts and contributions can continue beyond our earthly existence, and the progress we have made as individuals and as a society can be sustained and built upon in perpetuity.

argument.premise 1: If humans were immortal, they would have no fear of death and may not strive for progress in science and technology.
argument.premise 2: If humans do not strive for progress in science and technology, they will not achieve their true potential as a species.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, immortality could result in wasted potential for the human race.

argument.premise 1: There is a choice at present between pursuing immortality and not pursuing it.
argument.premise 2: At past times, humanity has invested significant resources into the quest for immortality, including research, experiments, and development of technologies.
argument.conclusion: Therefore, we should continue to pursue immortality as a way to not waste the resources and efforts that have already been invested towards it.

argument.premise 1: There is a choice at the age of 150 between immortality and not immortality
argument.premise 2: At the age of 150, I am pre-committed to not immortality because of what I did or committed myself to at the age of 30
argument.conclusion: Therefore, I should choose not immortality

argument.Position to Know Premise: As an immortal being myself, I am in a position to know whether immortality is possible or not.
argument.Truth Telling Premise: I have no reason to lie about the possibility of immortality, and as an immortal being, I have nothing to gain or lose from others believing me.

55.argument:

    "conclusion": "Por lo tanto, debe reconocerse una excepción a la regla y no obligar a las personas que tienen riesgos de salud por la vacunación a hacerlo, o proporcionarles alternativas seguras."
